title: Girl, 9, diagnosed with ovarian cancer after doctors said she was 'constipated'

Brave nine-year-old Kaylee Tolleson has beaten ovarian cancer inside four months - after doctors originally told her she was just constipated.

She soon found out she faced a battle for life after a soft, ball-sized tumour was discovered on her right ovary.

Kaylee began complaining of stomach pains late last year, but her issue was dismissed as a bowel complaint after the family took her to see a doctor.

But the girl's pediatrician soon made a horrifying discovery and an ultrasound confirmed the worst.

Kaylee dropped out of her Texas school and forgot all about ice-skating and girl scouts and she got ready for the fight of her young life.

Yet four months after being diagnosed, she rang the bell in the treatment centre to confirm her incredible recovery was complete.

"It feels amazing to ring the bell because everyone will know that I finally finished my chemo treatment, and that I'm cancer-free," Kaylee said in an interview with Texas Children's Hospital.

"I'm going to be getting out of here, busting my way out."

Her parents' lives changed once they heard the news everyone fears the most.

But proud Kelly Tolleson revealed the one thing that kept her daughter going - the weather forecast.

Kaylee is keen to become a meteorologist when she grows up and popular local weatherman Travis Herzog invited her to visit the studios after hearing her story.

"We almost fell off the chair when the doctor explained all of this to us," her mum said.

"I asked over and over again 'did it really spread? Where did it spread to?'

"'Please explain everything again' I asked - that was a hard day for everyone.

"Her world was turned totally upside down," she added. "Every thing was taken away: her ice skating, her Scouts, she couldn't even play outside.

"She was removed from school and couldn't complete her last 9 weeks of third grade."
description: Kaylee Tolleson, from Texas, took just four months to win her battle with the disease after a ball-sized tumour was removed
